yelled good-bye to him again just as I left, but

curtain.

smell of Raid and cooked broccoli? It's a lethal

bacon smoke or carpet lint. Coming home, in
my mind, will always be linked with the eternal
smell of broccoli in hallways. Maybe all vegetables, when boiled properly, smell like broccoli.

blow the scent of Raid and cooked broccoli

Upon Last Season's 5-7 Record
BY MIKE VOGELBAUM
With a longer schedule and a
larger squad than last year, this
year's wrestling team, coached
by former assistant coach John
Kohler, has set high goals for
itself.
The team has expanded its
schedule to 17 matches from 12
last year. The schedule will
include several Division I opponents.
This year, three seniors, two
juniors, four sophomores, and
three freshmen will take to the
mats for Hopkins. Last year's
team, which went 5-7, was
somewhat smaller. "The key ]to
this season] is not to forfeit
matches," Kohler said. "Hopefully we can fill all weights."
The lightweights will be
boosted as two of last year's
voids will be filled by Eddie
Brown, at 118, and John
Mandler, at 134. Kohler has
been impressed with Brown so
far. "He's got some good stuff
and he'll help us a lot," the
coach commented. Brown, however, is out with an illness and
may not return until after

Christmas. Ned Berg will compete at 126 pounds.
Returning to the team after
missing a year will be Kyle
Hicks, at 142. Hicks, a senior,
placed in tournaments two years
ago. Lee Wagstaff and Todd
Baker, when he recovers from an
injury, will also wrestle at 142.
Joel Eichler will compete at
150. Eichler, a sophomore, was
called "last year's most consistent freshman" by Kohler.
At 158 will be John
Mastrangello, and at 167 will be
Greg Haladyna. The coach remarked that the increase in
Haladyna's strength from last
year is "incredible." Haladyna
won about 3/4 of his matches
last year.
As for the heavyweights,
Rich Grohol will wrestle at 177,
Fran Mullen, at 177 or 190, and
Haswell Franklin at 190 or
unlimited. Franklin and Mullen
played football, so they are not
in shape to wrestle yet, according to Kohler. The newcomers to
the team, Jeff Greenspan, at
190, and Richard Chang, heavyweight, are "coming along pretty
well," said Kohler.

The major problem with the
team is a lack of depth. "Wrestling is probably the most demanding sport there is, and it
takes its toll," said Kohler. The
coach feels that many students
who have wrestled before will
not go out, because they are
afraid to do things that can hurt
them, such as lose weight.
Kohler added, "We're a
varsity sport in very heavy
academic environment.- The
team does not give scholarships;
the team members participate
because they want to wrestle."I
keep things in their proper
perspective and start from
there," explained Kohler.
As for this year's prospects,
Kohler feels he has "a better
team than last year." He thinks
the team can achieve a winning
season. Kohler added, though,
"Wrestling is an individual sport.
You have to look and see how
each wrestler improved from last
year." The coach feels that one
or two wrestlers will be able to
place in the tournaments. Last
year, none did.
